Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 22, 2012 04:21AM iatigger wrote: Happy Thanksgiving to all the October gals! I know even though I am finding myself coming to this site I am very thankful for the radiologist who gave me my early diagnosis, the surgeon who got rid of it and the PS who is rebuilding me. And thankful for the people who created this site so we have all the information and support at our fingertips to make this experience more tolerable. Enjoy today but don't eat too much :)
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2013 09:13AM iatigger wrote: MGDSMC glad you are healing well.  And congrats NYCMOM3 for on completing your first week of rads. I am still having weekly fills because the cancer side has decided not to be as stretchy as the other. I had hoped my swap would be the end of March but looks like that is out now. And this week was the first week since October that I have actually been uncomfortable after the fill. The muscle seems to be fighting back this time. And then my period showed up while on Tamoxifen. Now I have to call the MO on monday. She told me if I got it to call her so she can schedule an ultrasound to check for thickening.  Other than that I was in an organizing mood this morning and got an early start on my spring cleaning but now I am exhausted. May be a good afternoon for a movie and a nap. Have a great weekend gals!

Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2012 03:31PM iatigger wrote: Hi Gals, Just got my drains out after two weeks. They were still putting out 30 mls a day but the PS says he won't leave them in past two weeks. Didn't hurt at all pulling them out, yea! My DH said he wished he hadn't watched because he could see it moving under the skin when they pulled it out and it gave him the creepy crawlies LOL!  Going to start taking Tamoxifen tomorrow we will see what fun SE's I get from that. Waiting for the Oncotype DX test results that take 7-10 days to come back. Fingers crossed it is low. Hugs out to Connie and Cindy and anyone else have a frustrating day. Hoping tomorrow is better for you all.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2012 05:15AM iatigger wrote: hi Dulcigirl, I too am 3 wks out and I know what you are feeling. Mine does not sound as sensitive as yours but definitely feel it when anything touches, especially seat belts. I'm not sure if it is because the skin is getting stretched so much making the nerves more touchy or what but you are not the only one feeling it! I get my first fill since surgery on Tuesday so i will see if it gets worse or not. It is definately weird not feeling anything around the incisions but that has it's benefits.
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2012 04:19AM iatigger wrote: Dulcigirl, that is quit the dream, I can just picture it! lol Well gals today I get my first fill day since surgery. Yikes, not quite sure what to expect. I have made sure to keep doing my stretches and the exercise coach said my range of motion is great just afraid my comfort level will go out the window when I was just starting to not notice them so much. At least this is the last day of the annoying election calls and commercials! Happy Tuesday everyone!
Posts.Title: October 2012 Surgery? Leigh22 ConnieGreene

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2012 01:47PM iatigger wrote: I have been doing minimal stretching all along. Once the drains came out and I felt like I could drive safely I did. That was after week 2. I went shopping for a little while to get some walking in then came home for a nap. I also went to work with a cancer exercise coach that is part of the cancer wellness center at the hospital. Free to any cancer patients. He measures range of motion and works on stretching. Once past that point he will work on general exercise if I choose. I am constantly working on stretching even when sitting. It is amazing how quick it tightens up.

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2012 08:15PM iatigger wrote: Hi NYCMOM, I too was told no Chemo fortunately and I started Tamox 10/31. So far have no real side effects. Occasionally I will notice that I get a little warm when I haven't done anything to cause it but I don't consider it a major hot flash.  Since my DX I started eating better and riding my stationary bike a little more and I have lost weight so I think everyones response to Tamox is unique.  My periods have stopped since I had surgery but don't know if that is because of the Tamox or just an irregular cycle.  Hopefully you will have the same no side effect results when you start taking it.

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2012 12:16PM iatigger wrote: Hi KRCornett, I am a week out as well and go to the PS this afternoon for my first post visit. They took 8 sentinol nodes but all were clear as well as the margins. And since there was no node involvement I should be free from doing chemo. I am 47 and the oncologist I met with prior to surgery said it would only be Tamoxafen for me unless there was much greater involvement than expected. I see her on Friday for confirmation. Keeping fingers crossed.

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2012 09:02AM iatigger wrote: Hi Soteria, my surgeon takes out the affected nodes and has them tested during surgery to see if he needs to take more out which is really nice. Button down shirt is helpful the first few days. And I just set up some small tables next to my recliner to have my computer, kleenex note pad to keep track of when took pain meds, remotes and any other items with in close reach. Since I was just in overnight just took a hat to wear on the way home and the small pillow to hold up the seatbelt amazing how you feel every bump in the road. now i am living in my button down jammis, very comfortable. Sending positive thoughts your way, they worked wonders for me. -Aimee

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2012 05:44PM iatigger wrote: Positive thoughts going out to the ladies tomorrow. Anyway good luck Tuesday gals.

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2012 11:26AM iatigger wrote: Connie it is amazing how much better you start to feel once those buggers are out and you have that little freedom called driving back. I think it is a control thing. It is a bummer you have to move onto another stage of this bump in the road but from what I have seen on this website, there is always someone out there who has been through it before and is more than willing to help work through it. Sending positive thoughts your way that your chemo and rad experiences are side effect free and that it takes care of this nasty stuff once and for all. Politicomama- I asked that question of my PS at the two week mark and he said they could come off, so I made him do it :) Mine just looked like a big scab along the area. I still have some even after three weeks. Thank goodness that area is numb. He was a little concerned about a little necrosis on the one side so he put me back on antibiotics and the redness appears to be going away. My 12 yr old daughter has been curious all along so when she asked to see the scar I showed her. Didn't seem to phase her, just made it less scary for her wondering mind.

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2013 10:40PM iatigger wrote: Hi Pattszy, Our diagnosis are similar. My oncologist sent my tumor in for Oncotype testing to make sure there was no indication to do chemo. It came back an 8 so she said there was no way I would be doing chemo as the risks outweigh any possible benefit. So if you haven't heard of it ask your oncologist. I have been on Tamox since 10/31 and have done well, just a few warm flashes. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Recuperation after Bilateral Mastectomy Pattszy Pattszy

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2013 06:57AM iatigger wrote: Hopeful, I too had to play the waiting game for my surgery. The PS was on vacation right when I was diagnosed so had to wait for him to get back, meet with him and then the surgeon and his office came up with a date. It was almost a month after my diagnosis. I was really afraid to wait that long but my MO said it took this long to grow, a few more weeks wont be a problem. She was right, I had 0/8 node involvement. The hardest part was telling my 12 yr old daughter about the whole thing. I made sure to let the school counselor know ahead of time so my dd could go talk to her if she had issues while at school and she did a couple times but after a couple weeks she calmed down. Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2012 08:22PM iatigger wrote: Does anyone else ever feel almost guilty that we were so fortunate to be only stage 1? I am so thankful that is where my diagnosis fell. But then I have a close friend who joined the club 6 yrs ago and is now stage iv but is still winning the battle with her latest harsh treatment. Just knowing her and what she shared all along made the day i got the call so much easier. And she was so happy to find out I was not going to have to go through all the craziness she has. Guess I am just counting my blessings tonight and wish I could do more for the others that have to go through so much more. Lets hold the positive thought that none of us ever move off the Stage 1 thread!!!! -Aimee
